The Annual Virginia Conference Of the Mctil-
odst Episcopal Church, commence, its Session
in this place yesterday morning. We understand
that the Rev. bishops Mkendree, Roberts, and
soule, preside; and that about 10 Ministers be-
longing to the Itnerancy are here, besides num-
Der Of vsite,s from different quarters Of this and
the adjacent State. From the variety Of age,
experience, talents zeal, and piety, met togeth-
er from so many different sections Of Virginia
and North Carolina, on this occasion, our commu-
nifty and friends from the interior will be afford
ed an unusual opportunity ofrelglous enjoyment
and moral Improvement.

THE Subscriber tenders his services to the
citizens Wilmington, and county of New Castle,
in the capacity Of Surueyor of Land, and CoaoeV-
ancer, and hopes from his former experience in
Chester county, and by devoting his attention to
that business, that he will be able to give salts
faction to those who may be pleased to employ
him. His Office will be open at the corner of
Orange and Broad streets, until the 25th Of next
month, and afterwards at the house belonging
to Judge Way, in Queen street, next house to
John Whites China and Drug Store

announced the death of William Hogan, Esq.
Attorney at Law-iorlnery of Philadelphia. 1t

the editor had been imposed on, having received
communication from Mr.. Hogan himself deny

Larkin falsely charges Dr. Purcell with sowing
discord in the congregation-this we, the trus-
tees ofSt. Peters Church affirm to be false
hood. We offered Dr.. Purcell to take charge
of our funds, which he refused; and we are GER
tain nothing gives you more trouble than your
not getting hold of them. The balance of pew
rent and subscriptions to the church, which re-
manned in your hands at the time you were re-
moved from the office of Treasurer, you hold at
this time. You keep all our former books and
church accounts, and thereby the church sus-
tains great loss.


The pencil of an Angelo or Raphael-the
tongue of Cicero, Burk, Gratan, or Curran,
would not be adequate to describe the perfdy Of
that man. He is as dross among metal, chaff a.
mong grain, wolf among sheep, and a bad men,

Bernard M'Guigen, and John Durnin,

we now challenge you to come before any three

money, even for one dollar, since the commence

ry. intended BY the Legislature OF this State for

es were drawn, VIM l.arkin requested Inc to

ival.


.r act home within fifteen minutes of the
..,ct t;,,eI told nv wife, would get home.
Ehe was walking down the grove, upon the
WA was to come. aBNiously expecting my
mn;y,, So soon as saw her thus elese,
o,sted NV flap Of victory. She ran 70 meet

he flap and she fell PROSTATE on her face


afore me She then burst inta tears and

nn hrr arms about my knees, she called up
N the spirits of her father, her brothers


nd her sister TO bless me, and to interfere

S'hen rising up in alarm, she sa'd, ARE you


al, nv husband !" ] told her | was be-
E,ond the reach Of all that mortals could do
"a me: because the villain who had injured
her had fallen BY my arm. But, saio !, the
ayenger OF blood is after me-, then called

n briefly recounted to her all the circumstan-
ices Of the glorious deci.--And can truly
*sav. do not believe there ever lived upon
fthe earth, two more happy beings than we
3were; notwithstanding ! told my wife was
$confdcnt persons were in pursuit OF me aud
n even calculated they would be there that
syery night.--Dut Col Sharp had died by my
b,and Ill This consoled US for all misfortunes,
and made US perfectly regardless of danger


hen went to my house and set it in order
for battle and defence. For my dctermna-
lion was, il Doctor Sharp should be Of the
party who pursued me, would fight them;
Hor no Sharp ever should have obtruded him
kef into my yard, without being shot, while


was in it alive. Indeed hcsitAtcd great
ieal, whether would not shoot one or two
BIZ those who pursued me and then make my
Escape and leave the United States. And
had those who pursued me, have come that
hight, believe should have fought them.
But by the next day, had calmly come to
he resolution that | would rather die than
hy my country.--And as they had no shad
rw ct pyeot against rae, sresolvtd to go quite
k&uietly and cheerfully forward and submit
10 an investigation, should any one come tor
Pne. The night got home there was fell
ow by the name Of John Lowe, called there
bn some business, and staid some time, re-
uctant as he must have seen was to enter
nto any conversation with him. For l
wanted to get him off as soon as possible,
hnd while he staid. my wife and myself were
fetired, employed in my recitals of all the
mnutia of the murder; SO that we had
Scarcely any thing whatever to say to Lowe.
At length we got rid of him, and after had
prepared myself for battle, we went to bed.
AS was not molested that night. my renec-
tlons had led me to risk all the evidence the
Sharp family could get against me: little, ah!
little thinking the whole treasury Of the
Commonwealth would be thrown open as a
reward to villains to swear away my life
Next evening about an hour by sun. I saw
four men ride up to my gate and call to me
to come to the gate; recognized the face Of
one of them, the moment saw him, as be-
ing man had seen in Frankfort on Mon
day morning. was satisfied at once, they
were come to arrest me. But walked out
1 TO them with all the cheerfulness imagina-
bic, and one of them asked me if my name
was Beauchamp. said it was. He asked
me if had not lately been toFrankfort-l
told him 7 had just returned from there
the proceeding evening. They all paused
saw they were embarrassed. I had my
riiie in my hand, for I was cleaning and load
ing It in my yard, when they rode up. At
Il length one of the more frank and sensible of
q me men (Wm. Jackson said to me in a
feeling manner, that was suspected OF the
murder of Col. Sharp; and as a gentleman,


vas called upon and requested only. to SO
70 Frankfort and acquit myself. I put on a
iace OF great astonishment, to find myself
suspected, but promptly avowed my ready
determination to go Immediately to Frank
iort' il there was any thing said there, pre-
iaolclal to my reputation"

Mr.. Billy Larkin why are you barking at mel
We never had the change of an unpleasant word.
know of no cause of your slanderously abusing
me, excepting my refusing you to put my shoui-
der, as you termed it, to shove your improper
paper, which YOU called your accompt current,
Without day or date, truth, or even resemblance
oftiuth. showed it to Mr.. Wales, who IL one
of the four law agents employed against you.--
Do you state there is no suit sgainst you' but
you will find that you must get better security
than yourself. You forget the night that the
Rev. Mr. Keenan, spent the evening with me in
December last, when you intruded yourself in
to my house, without an invitation. You then
heard Mr. Keenan say he wished | would
come to Lancaster and live; and you also know
that MIR. Keenan, is parish priest in Lancaster;
and that he told you snever lived in Lancaster,
so that telling lies is as necessary for your
support as meat and drink. You forget when
you committed your falsehoods and defanlations
to be published, that your attack on me must
be founded on envy and falsehood; as the public
know that | advertise in this Borough in two
newspapers to let every enc in the United
States know who am, what am, and where
am, SO that you are, to make the most of you,
bad minded man. The principle cause, be-
lieve, of your behaviour, is my sending you back
a pound of spermaceti candles, which wanted
quarter of pound of the weight done SO to
prevent your doing So again-you, in an insolent
manner, told the woman that your weights were
as honest as mine. But this would not do, your
son had to give hera pound of candles, as she
paid YOU for them. This is one the causes OF
your savage lying, and yindictiye malice.


j. PURCELL.

III community VI WHICH tue foOCitt} pi /
Friends form so considerable a part Z cam |
not be unacceptable to the public, 70 state |
the extent of the cooperation of that benev-
olent Society in England. in the holy cause
of relieving the distresscs and suiferings Of
the Greeks. They display that degree Of
humanity. goodness and prudence, which
mark all the public proceedings of that es-
timable body of men. 1t is understood that
they sent an agent to superintend the distri- !
button of their supplies, not only to prevent
their being employed for military purposes,
but TO guard against misapplication other
wise.


E1tract from the Hestmin8tcr Reuic7e, PoL


ri. fage 116.


"Meanwhile the miseres and sutferings
produced by the intlscrimnate massacres
at SCio and Cyprus, and the destitution and
distress which the events of the war had en-
tailed on heihlcSs men, 7oonien and children,
who had been compelled to seek an asylum,
in different countries, from Turkish ftrocity
and barbarity, had led to the formation Of a
Committee among the Society of Friends,
who, without taking part in any political
question, had, with admirable generosity and
zeal, been laboring successfully to diminish
the afli ctiens of the Greeks. Many hundreds
of Greeks, who had been driven from the
southern and western provinces of Turkey,
from Wallachia, Madovia, and Macedonia,
and from the islands Of the Archipelago,
were enabled toreturn to their homes, others
have been assisted with pecuniary aid in
most of the ports OF Southern Europe. Med
icines and hospital stores were frequently
sent by the Friends, at the request of the
Committee, on board the same ships, which
carried supplies of military and naval am
muntion, and volunteers full Of ardor and
enthusiasm. m.--The exertions of this benevo-
lent body of men, as it removed from the
attention OF the Greek Committee, large
portion of distress enabled them, the Com
! mttee1 TO direct their views, anc 70 em-
plov their limited funds, ,rciusiveif For tle
political and military service of Greece"


"The money which the Quakers raised,
and which amounted to about ;E10,008, was
distributed by themselves in works of benev-
olence-in assistance rendered tofugtiye and
captive Greeks, and in the education ot
number of Grecian youth-The Quakers
are not accustomed to employ their resourc
es blindly or foolishly. ."-Idem, page lei.
To Naturalization a new edition of
the Cabinet Makers Guide, we quote the
following useful advice respecting the care
and management Of tools.


"The goodness of saws and chisels, and
other edge tools, depends upon the quality
of the steel, which should be uniform thro'
out. and it is always better to have them
tempered rather too hard than too soft, for
use will reduce the temper. If, at any time,
you wish to restore the temper, and to per-
form the operation yourself, the best method
is to melt sufficient quantity of lead to i'm
merse the cutting part of the tool. Having
previously frightened it's surface, then
plunge it into the melted lead few minutes,
till it gets sufficiently hot to melt candle,
with which rub its surface, then plunge it III
again, and keep it there until the steel as
sumes straw colour, (hut be careful not to
let it turn blue;) when that is the case, take
it out, rub it again with the tallow, and let
it cool; if it should be too soft, wipe the
grease off, and repeat the process without
the talow, and when sufficiently hot. plunge
it into cold spring water, or water and vim
egar mixed.


BY proper attention to these directions.
and little practice, every workman will
have it in his power to give proper temper
to the tools he may use


If "a saw is too hard, it may be tempered
by the same means. if you are near plumb
er's shop, you may repeat the process con-
vcniently and without expense, when they
are melting pot of lead.


'In other cutting tools you must wait
| till the steel Just begins to turn blue, which
city, and, at the same time, sufficient hard
ness"

Our latest accounts from the West Indies,
state that Com. Porter was still bockaded
at Key West by part OF the Spanish squad
ron from Havana. Laborde was said to be
cruising off Vera Cruz, no doubt look ing out
for the reinforcement expected to join the
Mexican feet. The situation of Com. Por-
ter must be considered critical. Labordc is
considered an officer Of superior skill and
courage, to almost any other il the Spanish
service, which, combined with the advan-
tage of double the force and weight of metal,
will give the odds in his favor. Porter
must risk an engagement or let his ship rot
III port, whilst he es@apes il small vessel


Several applications have been made 10 the
Greek committee in New-Nork, from individual.
and companies Of young men, desilous Of adven
turing in the service Of Greece, to be furnished
with a conveyance to that country.-Among the
applications of this nature, is one from conpa
ny Of so young men in I3elcl,erstown, Massachu
sets, who state themselves to be disciplined ir
cavalry tactics, and are desirous Of offering then
personal services in defence Of the rights of AT
oppressed people. Ono Of the applications il
made with the further offer of paying for theil
passages The committee, il is understood, have
declined their application, as no arrangements
have been made TO carry volunteers to Greece
It is the means of paving and clo'N ing her owl
heroic troops Of which she stands in need, and j
is for this object that the Greek committee arr
now engaged in obtaining contributions.

meeting of the Catholic Association, the pop
ulation of ireland is at present nearer NINE
than EIGHT millions. Of this number they
say that at least seven millions are Catllo-
lies. A fine material, says the London Morn
ing Chronicle, for foreign experiments, now
that steam vessels can land an army in def
ance of a Navy Of Observation, at any time,
and on any given point OF the country, fixed
ON for hostile operations.


A most outrageous riot occurred yester-
day, (Sunday) just as the people were going
to church In the afternoon, at the house in
the rear of building occupied by one DAILY,
boot and shoe maker, in Broad street, near
to Wall l-street.-From ten to twenty Irish
men, Of the rough and tumble order, with
sundry women, white and black, were en-.
gagged in grand battle. with SHADES, brick
bats, Shiliaiys, &c. One who was passing at
the time, took leave to so to the house and
ask the attention of Alderman Zebra, who
repaired to the place Immediately, and BY
bis vigorous and resolute conduct, succeed
ed in taking nine of the rioters and sending
them to Bridewell.-.N Y. States.

IN Red, Rlue or Black Colors, are handsomely
printed al the Office of the Wlmngtonian, No.
81, Market-st. on reasonable terms.--Orders will
meet with prompt attention.

Iarkin calls us self.created trustees--you
seem to forget the 18th of April 1924, when We
were the trustees, whom with the late and much
to be regretted Victor nu Pon, rejected your
rascally behaviour, and thrust you out ot being
Treasurer or Trustee ever since, III the Church.
The last day we met you was in Doctor Perceifs
shop, where you began your Old trade OF black
guaring us. You know you promised that
dav, which was the Esd Of january last, to bring
up your books, and appointed The Doctor to set
tie with the church on your part, and we ap-
pointed the late and revered Victor Du Pont on
our part; which you agreed to: alter, We saw


Mr. DUPONT he said if you would carry up your
books to Doctor Purcell to be examined, and ii
the doctor could do any thing with the backs re-
snectinr settlement, Mr.. Du Pont would call on
the Doctor on Saturday atter,to consult with him,
if thev could arrange q settlement. We return
ed to William Larkin and informed him Of what
Mr. Da Pont said to us-a.arkin's answer to us
was, he had no books, and would settle no ac-
counts See this unprlncipled man-cqually re-
gardless of his solemn promise. or OF committing
sacrilegc. His actions are the su.est standard
to Judge him by. After the Lottery was drawn
in January, 1924, we, the trustees ct st, Peters
Church, insisted on settlement from Larkin.-
What docs this monster Of iniquity do TO ann
hilate the church and trustees, 50 that, as he
supposed there would be none to demand the
proceeds of the Lottery Of him.--tie causes WI
liam Boyd sue the Church for the amount OF ms
BILL which was about $1,000, with an expectation
of Mr.. Boyds getting ajudgnent and execution
and then selling the house. He did not wish to
be bothered for Lottery money-he had better
use for it than giving it to St. Peter or ST. Paul


BY his Withholding from the Church the proceeds
of the Lottery, he withholds from the widow and
the orphan, and prevents numbers ofpoor chll
PAT,K HIGGINS.

Morgan Qgain.-The Orleans Advocate,
of the 18th inst. says, that "two gentlemen
stopped at the house of Mr.. Curtis, in Gaines,
in this county, ON the 18th who stated that
they were on their way with dispatches
from Sir p. Maitland, Lieut.. Gov. of Up
per Canada, to Gov. Clinton, announcing
that William Morgan was in the possession
of the former, subject to the direction Of the
latter alipe and zueH. They also stated that
they saw and conversed with Morgan. and
offered to produce their papers as vouchers
of the correctness of their statements-This
story is improbable and absurd on the face
of it. But in addition to this; Gov. Clinton
has authorized the editor of the Albany Dali
ly ADVERTISER, to say that he has received
no tidngs Of such import.

At recent dinner given to Sir Walter
Scott, his Majesty is reported to have re-
quested the worthy Baronet to write the his
tory of the Reign of George the Third; add
ing the assurance of free access to all the
papers and documents in the Royal Archives.
Sir w. is said to have declined the honour;
stating at the same time, his utter inability
to do justice to the subject.
< Even al
GT,n).EEl,HlSl25

METHODIST CONFEGENCE.
full articles.article:
The Annual Virginia Conference Of the Mctil-
odst Episcopal Church, commence, its Session
in this place yesterday morning. We understand
that the Rev. bishops Mkendree, Roberts, and
soule, preside; and that about 10 Ministers be-
longing to the Itnerancy are here, besides num-
Der Of vsite,s from different quarters Of this and
the adjacent State. From the variety Of age,
experience, talents zeal, and piety, met togeth-
er from so many different sections Of Virginia
and North Carolina, on this occasion, our commu-
nifty and friends from the interior will be afford
ed an unusual opportunity ofrelglous enjoyment
and moral Improvement.

full articles.headline:
Surveying Of LAND, and


CONVEYANCING.
full articles.article:
THE Subscriber tenders his services to the
citizens Wilmington, and county of New Castle,
in the capacity Of Surueyor of Land, and CoaoeV-
ancer, and hopes from his former experience in
Chester county, and by devoting his attention to
that business, that he will be able to give salts
faction to those who may be pleased to employ
him. His Office will be open at the corner of
Orange and Broad streets, until the 25th Of next
month, and afterwards at the house belonging
to Judge Way, in Queen street, next house to
John Whites China and Drug Store


I,GA PUSFY.
Wilmington, ID Mo. %, 49, 24--t25m

The Augusta (Geo) Courier Of the 10th nst
announced the death of William Hogan, Esq.
Attorney at Law-iorlnery of Philadelphia. 1t
appears, however, by subsequent paper, that
the editor had been imposed on, having received
communication from Mr.. Hogan himself deny
ing his death.

Larkin falsely charges Dr. Purcell with sowing
discord in the congregation-this we, the trus-
tees ofSt. Peters Church affirm to be false
hood. We offered Dr.. Purcell to take charge
of our funds, which he refused; and we are GER
tain nothing gives you more trouble than your
not getting hold of them. The balance of pew
rent and subscriptions to the church, which re-
manned in your hands at the time you were re-
moved from the office of Treasurer, you hold at
this time. You keep all our former books and
church accounts, and thereby the church sus-
tains great loss.


The pencil of an Angelo or Raphael-the
tongue of Cicero, Burk, Gratan, or Curran,
would not be adequate to describe the perfdy Of
that man. He is as dross among metal, chaff a.
mong grain, wolf among sheep, and a bad men,
Der among the children of God.


PETER PIERCE,


BERNARD MsGUiGEN,
]. PURCELL,
BERNARD M'CANN,
JOHN DURNIN.

full articles.headline: To THE pIIRIIc
full articles.article:
Bernard M'Guigen, and John Durnin,
with unjustly assailing, and most wantonly SIAN
dering, the said VIM Larkin's character. He
then proceeds to say he feels it duty he owes
to himsefand his friends to repel the unauthor-
ICED, base and unfonuded charges made by those
and expose them to that contempt
they merit. He then comes forward, honest
man like, to exhibit to public view statement of
the facts connected with the lottery case alluded
to: he requests the public to recollect the Pc
rod the Legislature granted the lottery, in 1922,
for raising the sum of 5000 dollars for the of
st Peters Church and payment fdebts over all
expenses: he then states the managers of the
lottery then agreed that one Of them should sign
the tickets, and receive the money, and pay
the przes--ths was the most substantial part of
the business, although poor Billy saysit was un-
fortunate for him, or as the setcrcated trustees
would have it, it was unfortunate for the Church
the trustees are a set Of impudent fellows, Tor
not plying poor Billy's severe loss, and not the
losses of the church poor Billy goes on to in.
form the public he sold the lottery to Thomas
Hope, who commenced to sell the Tickets; and
after the sale of the first and second classes, hen
est Billy tells the public with the most bare
faced fllschood, that he paid the church, in cash
and note. and payment ofdebts, the full amount
and upwards, say 1905 dollars. AS ne treats the


public opinion with the same inaolence as he has


treated the congregation of st. Peters Church,


we now challenge you to come before any three


or more respectable men Of the Borough, and we


are ready to meet any hour you appoint, face to


face, and if ;ol can produce one solitary docu-


ment Of a receipt or settlement for asy sum OF


money, even for one dollar, since the commence


mcnt of the drawing Of the lottery until this


day, we shall acknowledge your assertion to be


true, and ifyou cannot produce any receipt or


settlement from the trustees Of st. Peters


Church you must be the most abandoned crea-


ture upon earth-we challenge you to produce it
in forty-cight hours, you stand convicted, as
you are; so that we shall prevent you from
imposing any longer on the public. Our for
bcarancc for so long a time with you, was from


motives of charity, not wishing to injure your
character, as We would do, for any man i'll busi-
ness; but We you are the same obdnrate


and perverted wresth STILL after ell Our lndul-
gcnce to you. We point out an infamous false
/ hood on the face of the document you have set


before the public, where YOU say you sold six


classes Of the lottery 10 Thomas Hope for 500


dollars eacl, to be paid by Hope as each class


was sold You state that after the Isl and "a class


es were sold, you paid the church the sum OF
1906 dollars iii cash and note. You could not pay
ont of one thousand dollars, which you state you
sold the two classes for, you could not get
more shan 500 dollars for each class. Where


then did the sos dollars come from over the


prce of the two casscs' 50 that one might think
YOU wronged Hope, or made sham sale Of the
lottery, with an intent to t.eiraud the church.
| All, Mr.. Billy, we have documents from Thomas
| Hopes hand, which firmly prove that the
nett profits on the first class, after paying the


prizes, amounted to 1896 dollars and that the
/ profits on the second class amounted to 4765 dol
/ lars What IN unfortunate business for yoa!-


You say the third class was managed by Patrick
! fo1 r., fl,.an ptruJx
Z iSfateaem Of pa,riek Higgins.


/ ~ shall state as one oil The four managers of
! the Lottcry, sold by William Larkin, principal


manager and treasurer, who received the pro-
| cecds of the four classes Of the Delaware f.otte-


ry. intended BY the Legislature OF this State for


the use and benefit of St. Peters Church in this


Dsroueh,- that after the first and second class


es were drawn, VIM l.arkin requested Inc to


take the management of the Sd class, as he said


he was fatigucd. told him l would do any
! thing in nv power to assist the Church He


gave me the tickets, and some time after he
| came to me, with Arthur Murphy, and said he


would not sign the tickets unless Murphy and


would give him bill of indemnity, that in case


of loss in the third class, we should suffer like.
| As poor Murphy and knew nothing more of


Lottery schemes than an old woman, we signed
| the bond | now inform the public, that Will
| liam Larkn sometime after this, pulsuaded poor


Murphy to join with him and N. &. Williamsos,


and form Board of Managers, and take the


Lottery from me; which they did, and Larkin


and Tho's Hope sold it between them. After


they took the third class from me, Larkn sent
| his order to me to give Thomas Hope one thou


sand tickets, which order | hold to this day.
Al..io' he states in the paper that it was under
nv care the third class was sold. have Lar
! kn's order and Hopes receipt for every ticket
| he got from me. This is the rich harvest tho't
to save, which Iarkin acknowledges to have dis
appointed me in. He states the Sd class was all


under my care, which is false, as have his own
I order to prove it so. This order and all the do
cumcnts relative to the Lottery, gave to Doc


tor Purcell by order Of the Trustees so that, Lar
kin, every statement you made i'll the Whining


tonian is false, and inform the public that
know YOU these twenty five years, and that
have document relating to you, to prove what
! / say to be true.


PAT'k HIGGINS.
Iarkn calls MS selfcreated trustees--you
seem to forget the l3th of April 1924, when We
were the trustees, whom with the late and much
to be regretted Victor nu Pont, rejected your
rascally behaviour, and thrust yoa out OF being


Treasurer ora Trustee ever since, III the Church.
The last day we met you was in Doctor PerceiPs


shop, where you began your old trade OF black
guaring us. You know you promised that
dav, which was the Esd Of january last, to bring
up your books, and appointed thc Doctor to set
\ II ,t,.t

ina. st st,,l Ihad scen this was the great


lack,. .',;shr, 10 ascertain, but still tore


o'nt nv ;s,,,,;re why he asked me that ques.


ore ,nd nassed off the conversation as tho


Pon. a'iu tapr oui,e in etiquette. Nor did


haa ~. ,east notice of his mpolte inquiry,


NC w. business at Frank fort was, but an


ned Nd. ~ ali his impertinent inquiries with


w. cheerful frankness and truth, as tho


o,,.s,;ons had been a matter OF course.


ls .",-;nqleave OF lin, set off from his


he, .,hen the sun was about halt an hour


ou'e' When I spoke Of riding, he asked IT


lbn' ~ roinp to stay and see the House


wa;nsds wa. told him | should like very I


~ to do so, but that the ensuing Sunday


,uvn ,.sd anno;nted to start to the Missouri, and


iaa asnrs was compelled to hurry home


s;Ses said had some relations III


snroseld with whom was under prom


~ s,ay all night. that night, and there


va wished to set OFF early enough to get


IL returncd home, ffor we have not


-, "a notice the occurrences on the way,)


od he gives the following account OF his ar


ival.


.r act home within fifteen minutes of the
..,ct t;,,eI told nv wife, would get home.
Ehe was walking down the grove, upon the
WA was to come. aBNiously expecting my
mn;y,, So soon as saw her thus elese,
o,sted NV flap Of victory. She ran 70 meet
,e and as | ALT from my horse, gave her
he flap and she fell PROSTATE on her face


afore me She then burst inta tears and
Efted her voice in gratitude to Heaven that


hs was reyenred for all the misery vii
Ian had brought on her family. Then clasp
nn hrr arms about my knees, she called up
N the spirits of her father, her brothers


nd her sister TO bless me, and to interfere
pth e lust Providence, to protect me from
M harm for the righteous deed had done.
S'hen rising up in alarm, she sa'd, ARE you


al, nv husband !" ] told her | was be-
E,ond the reach Of all that mortals could do
"a me: because the villain who had injured
her had fallen BY my arm. But, saio !, the
ayenger OF blood is after me-, then called
Zservant to take my horse, and we walked to
/ a more retired spot where we sat down. aud
n briefly recounted to her all the circumstan-
ices Of the glorious deci.--And can truly
*sav. do not believe there ever lived upon
fthe earth, two more happy beings than we
3were; notwithstanding ! told my wife was
$confdcnt persons were in pursuit OF me aud
n even calculated they would be there that
syery night.--Dut Col Sharp had died by my
b,and Ill This consoled US for all misfortunes,
and made US perfectly regardless of danger


hen went to my house and set it in order
for battle and defence. For my dctermna-
lion was, il Doctor Sharp should be Of the
party who pursued me, would fight them;
Hor no Sharp ever should have obtruded him
kef into my yard, without being shot, while


was in it alive. Indeed hcsitAtcd great
ieal, whether would not shoot one or two
BIZ those who pursued me and then make my
Escape and leave the United States. And
had those who pursued me, have come that
hight, believe should have fought them.
But by the next day, had calmly come to
he resolution that | would rather die than
hy my country.--And as they had no shad
rw ct pyeot against rae, sresolvtd to go quite
k&uietly and cheerfully forward and submit
10 an investigation, should any one come tor
Pne. The night got home there was fell
ow by the name Of John Lowe, called there
bn some business, and staid some time, re-
uctant as he must have seen was to enter
nto any conversation with him. For l
wanted to get him off as soon as possible,
hnd while he staid. my wife and myself were
fetired, employed in my recitals of all the
mnutia of the murder; SO that we had
Scarcely any thing whatever to say to Lowe.
At length we got rid of him, and after had
prepared myself for battle, we went to bed.
AS was not molested that night. my renec-
tlons had led me to risk all the evidence the
Sharp family could get against me: little, ah!
little thinking the whole treasury Of the
Commonwealth would be thrown open as a
reward to villains to swear away my life
Next evening about an hour by sun. I saw
four men ride up to my gate and call to me
to come to the gate; recognized the face Of
one of them, the moment saw him, as be-
ing man had seen in Frankfort on Mon
day morning. was satisfied at once, they
were come to arrest me. But walked out
1 TO them with all the cheerfulness imagina-
bic, and one of them asked me if my name
was Beauchamp. said it was. He asked
me if had not lately been toFrankfort-l
told him 7 had just returned from there
the proceeding evening. They all paused
saw they were embarrassed. I had my
riiie in my hand, for I was cleaning and load
ing It in my yard, when they rode up. At
Il length one of the more frank and sensible of
q me men (Wm. Jackson said to me in a
feeling manner, that was suspected OF the
murder of Col. Sharp; and as a gentleman,


vas called upon and requested only. to SO
70 Frankfort and acquit myself. I put on a
iace OF great astonishment, to find myself
suspected, but promptly avowed my ready
determination to go Immediately to Frank
iort' il there was any thing said there, pre-
iaolclal to my reputation"

full articles.headline: March l, 1927.
full articles.article:
Mr.. Billy Larkin why are you barking at mel
We never had the change of an unpleasant word.
know of no cause of your slanderously abusing
me, excepting my refusing you to put my shoui-
der, as you termed it, to shove your improper
paper, which YOU called your accompt current,
Without day or date, truth, or even resemblance
oftiuth. showed it to Mr.. Wales, who IL one
of the four law agents employed against you.--
Do you state there is no suit sgainst you' but
you will find that you must get better security
than yourself. You forget the night that the
Rev. Mr. Keenan, spent the evening with me in
December last, when you intruded yourself in
to my house, without an invitation. You then
heard Mr. Keenan say he wished | would
come to Lancaster and live; and you also know
that MIR. Keenan, is parish priest in Lancaster;
and that he told you snever lived in Lancaster,
so that telling lies is as necessary for your
support as meat and drink. You forget when
you committed your falsehoods and defanlations
to be published, that your attack on me must
be founded on envy and falsehood; as the public
know that | advertise in this Borough in two
newspapers to let every enc in the United
States know who am, what am, and where
am, SO that you are, to make the most of you,
bad minded man. The principle cause, be-
lieve, of your behaviour, is my sending you back
a pound of spermaceti candles, which wanted
quarter of pound of the weight done SO to
prevent your doing So again-you, in an insolent
manner, told the woman that your weights were
as honest as mine. But this would not do, your
son had to give hera pound of candles, as she
paid YOU for them. This is one the causes OF
your savage lying, and yindictiye malice.


j. PURCELL.


February 98 1927 24-4tp.

full articles.headline: GREEK CAUSE.
full articles.article:
III community VI WHICH tue foOCitt} pi /
Friends form so considerable a part Z cam |
not be unacceptable to the public, 70 state |
the extent of the cooperation of that benev-
olent Society in England. in the holy cause
of relieving the distresscs and suiferings Of
the Greeks. They display that degree Of
humanity. goodness and prudence, which
mark all the public proceedings of that es-
timable body of men. 1t is understood that
they sent an agent to superintend the distri- !
button of their supplies, not only to prevent
their being employed for military purposes,
but TO guard against misapplication other
wise.


E1tract from the Hestmin8tcr Reuic7e, PoL


ri. fage 116.


"Meanwhile the miseres and sutferings
produced by the intlscrimnate massacres
at SCio and Cyprus, and the destitution and
distress which the events of the war had en-
tailed on heihlcSs men, 7oonien and children,
who had been compelled to seek an asylum,
in different countries, from Turkish ftrocity
and barbarity, had led to the formation Of a
Committee among the Society of Friends,
who, without taking part in any political
question, had, with admirable generosity and
zeal, been laboring successfully to diminish
the afli ctiens of the Greeks. Many hundreds
of Greeks, who had been driven from the
southern and western provinces of Turkey,
from Wallachia, Madovia, and Macedonia,
and from the islands Of the Archipelago,
were enabled toreturn to their homes, others
have been assisted with pecuniary aid in
most of the ports OF Southern Europe. Med
icines and hospital stores were frequently
sent by the Friends, at the request of the
Committee, on board the same ships, which
carried supplies of military and naval am
muntion, and volunteers full Of ardor and
enthusiasm. m.--The exertions of this benevo-
lent body of men, as it removed from the
attention OF the Greek Committee, large
portion of distress enabled them, the Com
! mttee1 TO direct their views, anc 70 em-
plov their limited funds, ,rciusiveif For tle
political and military service of Greece"


"The money which the Quakers raised,
and which amounted to about ;E10,008, was
distributed by themselves in works of benev-
olence-in assistance rendered tofugtiye and
captive Greeks, and in the education ot
number of Grecian youth-The Quakers
are not accustomed to employ their resourc
es blindly or foolishly. ."-Idem, page lei.
To Naturalization a new edition of
the Cabinet Makers Guide, we quote the
following useful advice respecting the care
and management Of tools.


"The goodness of saws and chisels, and
other edge tools, depends upon the quality
of the steel, which should be uniform thro'
out. and it is always better to have them
tempered rather too hard than too soft, for
use will reduce the temper. If, at any time,
you wish to restore the temper, and to per-
form the operation yourself, the best method
is to melt sufficient quantity of lead to i'm
merse the cutting part of the tool. Having
previously frightened it's surface, then
plunge it into the melted lead few minutes,
till it gets sufficiently hot to melt candle,
with which rub its surface, then plunge it III
again, and keep it there until the steel as
sumes straw colour, (hut be careful not to
let it turn blue;) when that is the case, take
it out, rub it again with the tallow, and let
it cool; if it should be too soft, wipe the
grease off, and repeat the process without
the talow, and when sufficiently hot. plunge
it into cold spring water, or water and vim
egar mixed.


BY proper attention to these directions.
and little practice, every workman will
have it in his power to give proper temper
to the tools he may use


If "a saw is too hard, it may be tempered
by the same means. if you are near plumb
er's shop, you may repeat the process con-
vcniently and without expense, when they
are melting pot of lead.


'In other cutting tools you must wait
| till the steel Just begins to turn blue, which
city, and, at the same time, sufficient hard
ness"

Our latest accounts from the West Indies,
state that Com. Porter was still bockaded
at Key West by part OF the Spanish squad
ron from Havana. Laborde was said to be
cruising off Vera Cruz, no doubt look ing out
for the reinforcement expected to join the
Mexican feet. The situation of Com. Por-
ter must be considered critical. Labordc is
considered an officer Of superior skill and
courage, to almost any other il the Spanish
service, which, combined with the advan-
tage of double the force and weight of metal,
will give the odds in his favor. Porter
must risk an engagement or let his ship rot
III port, whilst he es@apes il small vessel


Several applications have been made 10 the
Greek committee in New-Nork, from individual.
and companies Of young men, desilous Of adven
turing in the service Of Greece, to be furnished
with a conveyance to that country.-Among the
applications of this nature, is one from conpa
ny Of so young men in I3elcl,erstown, Massachu
sets, who state themselves to be disciplined ir
cavalry tactics, and are desirous Of offering then
personal services in defence Of the rights of AT
oppressed people. Ono Of the applications il
made with the further offer of paying for theil
passages The committee, il is understood, have
declined their application, as no arrangements
have been made TO carry volunteers to Greece
It is the means of paving and clo'N ing her owl
heroic troops Of which she stands in need, and j
is for this object that the Greek committee arr
now engaged in obtaining contributions.

OF forwardncss, and, according 70 The &C
count of it given by Mr.. O'Connell at late
meeting of the Catholic Association, the pop
ulation of ireland is at present nearer NINE
than EIGHT millions. Of this number they
say that at least seven millions are Catllo-
lies. A fine material, says the London Morn
ing Chronicle, for foreign experiments, now
that steam vessels can land an army in def
ance of a Navy Of Observation, at any time,
and on any given point OF the country, fixed
ON for hostile operations.


A most outrageous riot occurred yester-
day, (Sunday) just as the people were going
to church In the afternoon, at the house in
the rear of building occupied by one DAILY,
boot and shoe maker, in Broad street, near
to Wall l-street.-From ten to twenty Irish
men, Of the rough and tumble order, with
sundry women, white and black, were en-.
gagged in grand battle. with SHADES, brick
bats, Shiliaiys, &c. One who was passing at
the time, took leave to so to the house and
ask the attention of Alderman Zebra, who
repaired to the place Immediately, and BY
bis vigorous and resolute conduct, succeed
ed in taking nine of the rioters and sending
them to Bridewell.-.N Y. States.

IN Red, Rlue or Black Colors, are handsomely

81, Market-st. on reasonable terms.--Orders will
meet with prompt attention.

full articles.headline: PAT,K HIGGINS.
full articles.article:
Iarkin calls us self.created trustees--you
seem to forget the 18th of April 1924, when We
were the trustees, whom with the late and much
to be regretted Victor nu Pon, rejected your
rascally behaviour, and thrust you out ot being
Treasurer or Trustee ever since, III the Church.
The last day we met you was in Doctor Perceifs
shop, where you began your Old trade OF black
guaring us. You know you promised that
dav, which was the Esd Of january last, to bring
up your books, and appointed The Doctor to set
tie with the church on your part, and we ap-
pointed the late and revered Victor Du Pont on
our part; which you agreed to: alter, We saw


Mr. DUPONT he said if you would carry up your
books to Doctor Purcell to be examined, and ii
the doctor could do any thing with the backs re-
snectinr settlement, Mr.. Du Pont would call on
the Doctor on Saturday atter,to consult with him,
if thev could arrange q settlement. We return
ed to William Larkin and informed him Of what
Mr. Da Pont said to us-a.arkin's answer to us
was, he had no books, and would settle no ac-
counts See this unprlncipled man-cqually re-
gardless of his solemn promise. or OF committing
sacrilegc. His actions are the su.est standard
to Judge him by. After the Lottery was drawn
in January, 1924, we, the trustees ct st, Peters
Church, insisted on settlement from Larkin.-
What docs this monster Of iniquity do TO ann
hilate the church and trustees, 50 that, as he
supposed there would be none to demand the
proceeds of the Lottery Of him.--tie causes WI
liam Boyd sue the Church for the amount OF ms
BILL which was about $1,000, with an expectation
of Mr.. Boyds getting ajudgnent and execution
and then selling the house. He did not wish to
be bothered for Lottery money-he had better
use for it than giving it to St. Peter or ST. Paul


BY his Withholding from the Church the proceeds
of the Lottery, he withholds from the widow and
the orphan, and prevents numbers ofpoor chll

Morgan Qgain.-The Orleans Advocate,
of the 18th inst. says, that "two gentlemen
stopped at the house of Mr.. Curtis, in Gaines,
in this county, ON the 18th who stated that
they were on their way with dispatches
from Sir p. Maitland, Lieut.. Gov. of Up
per Canada, to Gov. Clinton, announcing
that William Morgan was in the possession
of the former, subject to the direction Of the
latter alipe and zueH. They also stated that
they saw and conversed with Morgan. and
offered to produce their papers as vouchers
of the correctness of their statements-This
story is improbable and absurd on the face
of it. But in addition to this; Gov. Clinton
has authorized the editor of the Albany Dali
ly ADVERTISER, to say that he has received
no tidngs Of such import.

At recent dinner given to Sir Walter
Scott, his Majesty is reported to have re-
quested the worthy Baronet to write the his
tory of the Reign of George the Third; add
ing the assurance of free access to all the
papers and documents in the Royal Archives.
Sir w. is said to have declined the honour;
stating at the same time, his utter inability
to do justice to the subject.
